Award.AwardTitle: Type 2 Collaborative Project: Integrating Testing into Advanced CS/IT Courses Supported by a Cyberlearning Environment

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Ensuring the quality of software systems in the 21st Century requires an improved pedagogical approach to teaching software testing that exploits the cyberinfrastructure currently accessible to academic institutions and the social networking inclinations of our students. Two main factors highlight the need to provide students in the computing disciplines with greater access to learning materials on software testing: the high cost associated with the production of software systems that contain errors and the need to adequately train future software engineers and computer programmers since these occupations are projected to increase by 21% from 2008 to 2018.

This project is creating new cyberlearning materials on software testing and improving faculty expertise in the knowledge and use of software testing techniques and tools by: (1) creating a cyberlearning environment (WReSTT ? Web-based Repository of Software Testing Tutorials) that provides students and instructors with access to tutorials on software testing concepts and tools; (2) conducting workshops to develop faculty expertise in software testing and using the features in WReSTT to support pedagogy; (3) fostering students? acquisition of software testing concepts and skills in undergraduate programming courses; and (4) promoting WReSTT and disseminating the research findings to the academic community. The project team consists of experienced instructors and evaluators from a cross-section of institutions, including institutions with students from underrepresented groups. Three industry partners support the project by serving on the project?s advisory board, presenting testing tool tutorials at faculty workshops, and making testing tools available to students at academic institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ensuring the quality of software systems in the 21st Century will require changes in software development strategies, and improvement in the pedagogy used to teach these strategies in academia. Improvements in pedagogy require that academic institutions play a greater role in training students to test software and in making students aware of the tools available to support software testing.   Achieving such a goal is made easier by providing academic institutions with a cyberlearning infrastructure that contains learning content on software testing and testing tools.

 

This project was a collaborative effort between Florida International University (FIU), Alabama A&M University (AAMU), Miami University (MU) and North Dakota State University (NDSU).  During the project WReSTT-CyLE, Web-based Repository of Software Testing Tutorials: A Cyberlearning Environment, was developed to provide students and instructors with guided access to learning content in the area of software testing. The learning content is in the form of learning objects (small chunks of knowledge with practice and assessment items) and tutorials on software testing tools.  Currently WReSTT-CyLE contains 11 learning objects on various testing techniques and 9 tutorials on various testing tools.  The URL for WReSTT-CyLE is as follows: http://wrestt.cis.fiu.edu/

 

The project provided training to academic instructors in the area of software testing and the use of testing tools.  During the project five (5) workshops were held, these workshops included 4 workshops held at Florida International University (FIU) and one workshop at the 45th ACM technical symposium on Computer science education (SIGCSE '14).  On average per year there were: 19 applications per workshop, 14 of the applicants attended the workshop, and in total 27 participants (including investigators and students) attended the workshop from 18 different academic institutions. At least 25% of the academic institutions represented at the workshops were considered as minority serving institutions.

 

Post instructor workshop surveys indicated that instructors rated the workshop as useful and relevant for their courses, questions regarding the workshops’ impact ranged from 3.47 to 4.21 (out of 5). Instructors generally viewed the workshops as helping them acquire new knowledge relevant to their course work, with ratings on knowledge acquisition ranging from 3.89 to 4.21 (out of 5). Since attending the workshops, 63% of instructors indicated that they had spent at least a moderate amount of time further exploring WReSTT-CyLE.

Details of the workshops can be found at http://wrestt.cis.fiu.edu/events

 

Data captured from WReST-CyLE showed that 1279 users were registered in WReST-CyLE. These users included 1245 students and 28 professors from 23 academic institutions. There were 35 course templates created and 67 instances of the courses created for instructors.  The 11 learning objects (LOs) in WReSTT-CyLE were assigned a total of 183 times. Students posted to the forums 66 times; commented on learning objects 372; and accessed courses 4695 (unique logins greater than 12 hours apart).  The LO statistics include: 626 out of 1245 students submitted 2454 LO assignments; students on average scored 70% on LO assignments; and on average students attempted each LO assignment 4 times.

 

Student studies were conducted at all four institutions participating in the project. The results of student surveys showed that students benefited from the learning content in WReSTT-CyLE. Overall, students rated the WReSTT-CyLE as user friendly and with good functionality. Ratings for questions regarding User Experience and usability ranged from 3.10 to 3.94 (out of 5). Students generally viewed the software testing tutorials available in WReSTT-CyLE as good, with ratings for questions regarding the tutorials ranging from 3.28 to 3.44 (out of 5). Student ratings of the collaborative learning approaches used in WReSTT-CyLE ranged from 3.36 to 3.59 (out of 5).  Areas of improvement include: increasing the number of tool tutorials, more interactive activities as part of the learning process, a need for more tools for direct student-to-student and student-to-instructor communication, such as chat or email modules.  The results of the student studies are published in the papers found at the following URL: http://wrestt.cis.fiu.edu/documentation

Videos are posted to YouTube that help users understand how to use WReSTT-CyLE.  These videos can be found at the following links:

 Professor help video: https://youtu.be/JDDEbIVro30

 Student help video: https://youtu.be/fZfgCFV5HFM

 

As a result of the success of this project a new Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Design and Development grant was awarded to the project team to enhance WReSTT-CyLE.  These enhancements include: extending the learning content to include content on software engineering and programming courses, provide students access to various learning and engagement strategies in the cyberlearning environment, perform studies to include a wider cross-section of students, and continue with the instructor workshops.
